sp.p: He ſhall go to the ſtocks, if he is.—What, not yield when the intereſt of my darlings is in queſtion? By all that's ſteady, I'll build a new houſe of correction, and they ſhall keep the key.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: But be upon your guard, Sir; he will be aſſerting his former reſolutions.

l.hi: Tell not me of his aſſertions,
Mine are laws of Medes and Perſians;
Vain againſt them all endeavour,
Right or wrong they bind for ever.
Remember then a daughter's prayer,
Receive a parent to your care;
Frown on his foe's obdurate plea,
But keep benignant ſmiles for me.
When I ſee my betters hearty,
How I long to be a party!
Pardon me if I intrude, Sir;
I'd be pleaſant, but not rude, Sir.
From hence he goes,
To cruſh our foes.

p.hi: As Jack did once the Giant.
Remember your clients with troubles beſet.

l.hi: The cauſe of my clients I'll never forget,
The kiſs of Sophia, the kiſs of Annette.

div.head: ACT III. SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Peggy and La Nippe (following and courting).

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: IF you offer to be impudent again, you ſhall have it on both ears inſtead of one. I tell you I'm a married woman; is not that an anſwer?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Yes, of encouragement, my dear—it ſeldom is an objection in the world I have inhabited.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: The world is at a fine paſs by your account—"But theſe are ſome of your outlandiſh notions—they wou'd make fine cutting of throats among Engliſh huſbands.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE
sp.p: "Cutting throats! Oh, my ſweet Peg, how ignorant you are! I wiſh your huſband was at home with all my heart—I'd ſhew you how to follow the example of our betters—I wou'd dine with you both every day, and he ſhould thank me for preſerving the peace of his family.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: "Keep your diſtance, Mr. Aſſurance"—If this be the new ſtyle of matrimony, Heaven keep Sophia clear of it, I ſay.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Oh my dear, you need be in no pain about that. She is not in the leaſt danger.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Why, did not you tell me your maſter was mad in love for her, and wou'd make my fortune if I wou'd help him?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Exactly! but what has that to do with marriage?

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: What the deuce has it to do with elſe?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Pleaſure and profit. He'll love her out of vanity if ſhe makes a figure as his miſtreſs; he'd hate her for faſhion's ſake if ſhe was his wife. Let us but get the couple well eſtabliſhed in London—who knows but you and I may be exalted to be their toads.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Toads!

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p:
One takes any name for a fortune, and this is become a faſhionable one I aſſure you. In ſhort you
will be the companion of her pleaſures; dreſs'd as well as herſelf; courted by every man who has a deſign upon her—and make a market of her every day. Oh, you'll have quite the pull of me in employment.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Yes, I ſhall change damnably for the worſe in quitting the life of a valet for that of a companion. "Follower to what he calls a man of faſhion! zounds I'd rather be a bailiff's follower by half—if it was not for what may come after.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: I have no longer any patience with the Rogue's impudence! (aſide.)
"So having declar'd yourſelf a pimp—you wou'd make me a procureſs, and Miſs Sophy a—

sp.speaker: LE NIPPE
sp.p: "Hold your tongue, you jade—and don't give groſs names to characters ſo much in faſhion." Come, don't be ſilly and angry now—I have dealt openly with you, knowing you to be a woman of ſenſe and ſpirit—
Don't be in a paſſion I tell you—here my dear—here's a gentle receipt for anger—here—did you ever ſee this ſort of thing before?
sp.stage: [Takes a rouleau of guineas from his pocket.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE
sp.p: A rouleau! fifty guineas wrapt up in this ſmall compaſs. One may know it by its make, it is from the firſt club in town—there it is, eſcaped from ſharpers and creditors, to purchaſe beauty and kindneſs.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: I cou'd tear his eyes out—is there no way to be even with him?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Aye, take a minute my dear to conſider—I know but few of your ſex wou'd require ſo much time.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: No means of fitting the rogue! Gad I have a thought—if I am not too much in a paſſion to diſſemble—I am not much uſed to artifice—but they ſay it never fails a woman at a pinch.
Why to be ſure, I was conſidering upon that little device—let's feel, is it heavy?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Oh! of great weight.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Law not at all, I cou'd carry a hundred of them—but pray now tell me fairly what am I to do for it?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Nothing but an office of good-nature—you are to put your miſtreſs into my maſter's hands—you women can do more with one another in this ſort of buſineſs in a day, then a lover (at leaſt ſuch a one as ours) will do in a year.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Lord, how modeſt you are all at once—ſpeak out—I am to ſeduce my miſtreſs for—

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Fye, what names you are giving things again!—you are to remove fooliſh prejudices; to open a friend's eyes to their intereſt—zounds child it's an office for a ſtateſman.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Oh, that's all—

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Not quite all; you know there's a ſomething that regards ourſelves, but that goes of courſe in negociations of this ſort.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Oh, does it?—and what do you call this pretty invention?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p:
An abridgement of polite arithmetic—a purſe muſt be counted, which is troubleſome; a note requires
reading, which to ſome perſons may be inconvenient—but the rouleau conveys fifty guineas to your pocket without a ſingle chink, and takes up leſs room than a toothpick caſe.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: This bewitches me, I think,

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, it's always reckon'd bewitching.

lg.l: The rouleau is form'd with a magical twiſt,

l.hi: To conquer caprice or diſpleaſure:

lg.l: If your object the offer of one ſhould reſiſt,

l.hi: You have only to double the meaſure.
It finds to all places its way without eyes,
Without tongue it diſcourſes moſt ſweetly;
To beauty or conſcience alike it applies,
And ſettles the buſineſs completely.
Well, who could have thought ſuch a wonderful pow'r,
In a compaſs ſo ſmall could be hidden;
To ſweeten at once the grapes that are ſour,
And purchaſe e'en fruit that's forbidden:
A magic ſo pleaſant muſt ſurely be right,
Without ſcruple I pocket the evil,
I'll ſhew you the proper effect before night,
And leave you to account with the devil.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Excellent! now you are a girl exactly after my own heart—where ſhall we meet?

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know this is the day of our wake; and Sir John gives a treat to all the tenants, ſo every body will be buſy, and ſo about an hour before ſun ſet come to the hay rick by the poole of the farm yard.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Oh, you jade, I ſhall have no patience if you make me wait.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: I'll come whenever I am ſure the coaſt is clear—but in the mean time you ſhall find a harveſt cag, with a ſup of cordial to keep up your ſpirits; in the country we never make a bargain with dry lips.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE
sp.p: What the devil, my dairy-maid drinks drams!—ſhe'll be fit to cry milk in the ſtreets of London—I need not have paid ſo high if I had known that.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Be ſure now to be punctual.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: And you to be complying.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Oh, as for that you know—"If your object your offer of one ſhould reſiſt" &c.

div.stage: Scene—Booths for a country wake—a large one in the form of a tent—recruits in different colour'd cockades at work in fitting it up.

sp.speaker: CAPTAIN TREPAN.
sp.p: Come, ſtir my lads—briſkly, briſkly—up with the reſt of the advertiſements—we ſhall have the wake fill'd before we are ready.
Hey day! what have we here? if you have any ſhew to exhibit friend, you ought to aſk leave before you erect your booth.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Ah, ſir, the Lord of the Manor is too good a ſubject to obſtruct my work.— (To the workmen) Bring forward the great Butt there, place it in view by the drum and colours.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: By your dreſs you ſhould belong to the army; pray, ſir, what is your real buſineſs?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: I am a manufacturer of honor and glory—vulgarly call'd a recruiting dealer—or more vulgarly ſtill, a ſkin merchant. I come to a country wake as to a good market—a little patience, and you ſhall ſee my practice—come paſte up more bills—and the devices—they are not half thick enough—where's the lyon rampant, with a grenadier's cap upon his head?

sp.speaker: 1ſt WORKMAN.
sp.p: Here, ſir, here.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: And the marine device?

sp.speaker: 2d WORKMAN.
sp.p: Here it is—done to the life—the prize boarded; the decks running with arrack punch, and dammed up with gold duſt.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Right lad, place that next the lyon. I don't ſee the London Taylor with his foot upon the neck of the French king.

sp.speaker: 3d WORKMAN.
sp.p: Here he is in all his glory.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Paſte him up on the other flank of the lyon—ſo, ſo, pretty well—what have you left for the corner?

sp.speaker: 4th WORKMAN.
sp.p: The Eaſt-Indies, Captain, a nabob in triumph, throwing rough diamonds to the young fifers to play at marbles.

sp.speaker: TREPAN
sp.p: Very well, very well—ſir, how do you like my ſhop.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Faith, ſir, the conſtruction ſeems to be as curious as your employment—I think you call'd yourſelf a ſkin merchant.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Mine, ſir, is a new trade, but a neceſſary and a happy one, for it flouriſhes in proportion to the ſpirit of the nation—and if our rulers will but employ it properly—Captain Trepan ſhall furniſh them for next year with twenty thouſand new Alexanders at five pence a day.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Well, captain, as you have call'd your's a trade, will you oblige me ſo much as to explain how it is carried on?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p:
Oh, with pleaſure, ſir! ſuppoſe new regiments are to be raiſed—I am applied to—Captain Trepan—that's my name, ſir—How are ſkins now?—how many may you want?—five hundred—Why, your honor, anſwers I, thoſe that are fit for all uſe, that
bear fire, and wear well in all climates, cannot be affoarded for leſs than ten pounds a piece—we have an inferior ſort that we ſell by the hundred—I'll take half and half ſays my employer!—your place of delivery?—Plymouth!—agreed!—and they are on ſhipboard in a month.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: But captain, ſure this buſineſs is ſubject to frauds?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Yes, there are rogues in all trades—but my word is known. I never run the ſame recruit thro' more than three regiments in my life—and that only when we have been hard preſſed for a review.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Very conſcientious, upon my word.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Aye, and my conſcience has made me—I export more goods than all the trade together. Let us but have a fair trial with our enemies in any part of the world—and then ſee if captain Trepan's ſkins don't figure—but here, ſerjeant Crimp, let the recruits fall in.

sp.speaker: RENTAL
sp.p: "Very fine language, Captain—I ſee you are a great writer as well as an orator.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p:
"I cou'd not do without the talents of both, Sir—next to gold and brandy, a glib tongue and a ready
pen are the beſt implements in our trade—novelty in every line, you ſee—new cloaths, new arms, new commanders, new—

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: "There I doubt a little, whether novelty is ſo proper—would not old commanders be more encouraging?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: "No it is not thought ſo—old commanders, like old wines, may be good to ſtick to; but the new ſparkles, and gets into the head, and preſently makes it fit to be run againſt the wall"—ſee how my new Colonels ſtand over the old ones with their names in capitals as tall as their ſpontoons.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Arranged with a great deal of fancy indeed.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Aye, and meaning too—I can tell you—but do only look at my recruits—do but look at them—
there's ſtuff for all work—ſouthern rangers, and northern hunters—low-landers and high-landers, and loyals and royals, and chaſſeurs and daſheurs—I ſuppoſe now you would like ſuch a fellow, as that.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: It is a thouſand pities he ſhould be ſhot at.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Be in no apprehenſion, he'll never die by powder.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Lord help you, how you might be impoſed upon—he's my decoy-duck—mere ſhew goods for the ſhop window—not an inch of wear and teat in the whole piece.—The dog inherited deſertion from his family. His brother was called Quick-Silver Jack, he was hanged at laſt at Berlin, after having ſerved ſix different princes in the ſame pair of ſhoes.
Which is the commander of the party?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Your pleaſure, Sir.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: A muſquet in a regiment upon foreign ſervice.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: And a handful of guineas to boot, my lad of mettle; this is ſomething like a recruit.

sp.speaker: Rental
sp.p: What's this—Trumore enliſting—can I believe my eyes?

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Yes, and your heart too—which is always on the ſide of a well-meant action.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: What has driven you to ſuch an act of deſperation?

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Raſhly quits the country—I am convinced his repugnance to my union with his daughter is the cauſe. He is provident—I am undone—he is beſides in immediate trouble—perhaps going to jail upon informations for killing game—I muſt give him a proof of my reſpect and my friendſhip—as well as of my reſignation.

sp.speaker: RENTAL
sp.p: Generous youth—but I'll let all things go on—if they do not unitedly work upon the old man's heart, it muſt be adamant. Captain, you'll ſee Sir John Contraſt.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: I ſhall atteſt my recruits before him, and this brave fellow at their head.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: I ſhall be ready, but there is a condition muſt firſt be complied with.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Twenty guineas to make up a ſum for an indiſpenſible obligation—I ſcorn to take it as enliſting money—you ſhall be repaid.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: You ſhall have it—any thing more?

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Abſence for half an hour—in that time depend upon't I'll meet you at the Caſtle.
Here's a fine ſet of country fellows getting round us, a march and a ſong might do well.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: (Aſide) You are right!

(Aloud) Come, my lads, we'll give you a taſte of a ſoldier's life. Corporal Snap—give them the ſong our officers uſed to be ſo fond of—it will pleaſe their ſweethearts as well as themſelves—ſtrike up drums.

l.hi: Gallant comrades of the blade,
Pay your vows to beauty.
Mars's toils are beſt repaid,
In the arms of beauty.
With the myrtle mix the vine,
Round the laurel let them twine;
Then to glory, love, and wine
Pay alternate duty.
Gallant comrades, &c.

div.stage: Enter Peggy, with an empty cag laughing.

sp.p: The rogue has drank it every drop; poppy water and cherry brandy together work delightfully—he'll ſleep ſome hours in a charming ditch where I have had him convey'd—pleaſant dreams to you, monſieur La Nippe. What wou'd I give if I cou'd requite your maſter as well.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: My life on't the dog's off—the moment Trepan told me of his pelaver—I ſuſpected he was an old hand—with his voluntary ſervice—and his honour—and his half hour.
Miſtreſs, did you ſee a young fellow with a ſcarlet cockade in his hat paſs this way?

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Not I, indeed, friend—I was otherways employed.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p:
Nay, don't be croſs—we are looking for a deſerter—he is deſcribed as a likely young fellow—come, if
you can give me intelligence, you ſhall have half the reward for apprehending him.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Here's another bribe—one may have them, I ſee, for betraying either ſex. And what would you do with him?

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Oh, no harm, as it is the firſt fault. We ſhould put him in the black hole at preſent, juſt to give him the reliſh of bread and water; the party marches at midnight; he'll be handcuffed upon the road; but as ſoon as he gets between decks in a tranſport—he'll be perfectly at liberty again.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Gad, whoever he is, if I cou'd ſee him, I'd give him a hint of your intended kindneſs.

Hey! who's this coming—the hero of the plot, young Contraſt (ruminates) it wou'd be ſpecial vengeance—a bold ſtroke its true—but a public juſtice to woman kind—hang fear—I'll do't—hark ye—Mr. what d'ye call 'em—did you ever ſee the man you are in ſearch of?

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: No, but I think I ſhould know him.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: That's your mark, I fancy.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Gad it muſt be ſo—but I don't ſee his cockade.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: I ſaw him pull it off, and throw it in the ditch as he came over yonder ſtile.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Ah! an old hand, as I ſuſpected—meet me at the Caſtle, where we ſhall convict him—you ſhall have the reward.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: To be ſure, money does every thing; but have ſome pity upon the young man—you won't treat him worſe than what you told me.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: No, no, get you gone, he'll never know who did his buſineſs.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: But don't treat him hardly?—

div.stage: Enter Contraſt yawning—Crimp comes behind and taps him upon the ſhoulder.

sp.p: Well overtaken brother ſoldier.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Friend, I conclude you are of this neighbourhood, by the happy familiarity that diſtinguiſhes it; but at preſent it is miſapplied, you miſtake me for ſome other.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Miſtake you—no, no, your legs wou'd diſcover you among a thouſand—I never ſaw a fellow better ſet upon his pins.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST
sp.p: Not ſo much out there.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: But where have you been loitering ſo long? is your knapſack packed? have you taken leave of your ſweetheart?—ſhe muſt not go with you, I can tell you—we are allowed but four women a company for embarkation, and the officers have choſen them all already.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Sure there is ſome ſtrange quality in this air—the people are not only impudent—but mad.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: I ſhall find a way to bring you to your ſenſes, ſir; what did you pull the cockade out of your hat for, you dog?

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: What the devil can he mean?

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Why, you raſcal, you won't deny that you are enliſted to embark immediately for the Weſt-Indies? have not you touched twenty guineas for the legs you are ſo proud of? pretty dearly bought.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Now it's plain how well you know me—thy own gunpowder ſcorch me, if I'd lie in a tent two nights to be Captain General of the united Potentates of Europe.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: The dog's inſolence out-does the common—but come, walk on quietly before me.—

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Walk before you!—

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Oh, oh! mutinous too—

sp.speaker: 1ſt SOLDIER.
sp.p: Here we are, ſerjeant! what are your orders?

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Lay hold of that fellow—he's a deſerter—a thief—and the ſaucieſt dog in the army.—Have you no handcuffs?

div.stage: Enter Moll Flagon—A ſoldier's coat over her petticoat, a gin bottle by her ſide, and a ſhort pipe in her mouth.

sp.speaker: MOLL.
sp.p: No occaſion for 'em, maſter ſerjeant—don't be too hard upon the young man—brandy be my poiſon but I like the looks of him—hear my heart—take a whiff— (offers her pipe)—what, not burn priming! come load then.—

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: It is plain theſe are a ſet of murderers—no help! no relief!

sp.speaker: MOLL.
sp.p: Relief, ſirrah! you're no centry yet. Serjeant, give me charge of him—Moll Flagon never fail'd when ſhe anſwer'd for her man.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: With all my heart, honeſt Moll!—and ſee what you can make of him.—

sp.speaker: MOLL.
sp.p: Never fear, I'll make a ſoldier and a huſband of him—here, firſt of all—let's ſee—what a damn'd hat he has got—here, change with him Jack.—

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Why, only hear me—I'm a man of faſhion—

sp.speaker: MOLL.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I'll faſhion you preſently—
There, now you look ſomething like—and now let's ſee what caſh you have about you.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Very little—but you ſhall have it every farthing if you'll let me go.

sp.speaker: MOLL.

l.hi: Come my ſoul
Poſt the cole,
I muſt beg or borrow:
Fill the can,
You're my man;
'Tis all the ſame to-morrow.
Sing and quaff,
Dance and laugh;
A fig for care or ſorrow,
Kiſs and drink,
But never think;
'Tis all the ſame to-morrow.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Oh, I am a man of faſhion.

div.stage: Enter Sophia and Annette, croſſing the ſtage haſtily—Trumore after them.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Stop, Sophia.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Trumore, this is the only moment I cou'd refuſe liſtening to you. My father is, for aught I know, going to jail.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Comfort yourſelf on his part—I promiſe you his ſafety. I would not leave the county 'till I was certain of it. I now take leave of him—of you—and all that makes life dear.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Oh my fears! what means that ribband in your hat?

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: The enſign of honor, when worn upon true principles. A paſſion for our country is the only one that ought to have competition with virtuous love—when they unite in the heart, our actions are inſpiration.

l.hi: From thine eyes imbibing fire,
I a conqueror mean to prove;
Or with brighter fame expire,
For my country and my love:
But ambition's promiſe over,
One from thee I ſtill ſhall crave;
Light the turf my head ſhall cover,
With thy pity on my grave.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Trumore, this is too much for me—heaven knows how little I am formed for the reliſh of ambition—theſe heroic notions, how often do they lead to the miſery of ourſelves!—of thoſe we leave!—I claim no merit in my apprehenſions—alas, they are too ſelfiſh.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: I came to bid farewell in one ſhort word; but the utterance fails me—Annette, ſpeak for me; and when I am gone, comfort your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: ANNETTE.
sp.p: Indeed, Trumore, it will be out of my power—my notes will now be as melancholy as her own—to ſooth her, I muſt ſympathize with her in the alarms of abſence and danger.

l.hi: The ſleepleſs bird from eve to morn
Renews her plaintive ſtrain;
Preſſes her boſom to the thorn,
And courts th' inſpiring pain.
But, ah! how vain the ſkill of ſong,
To wake the vocal air;
With paſſion trembling on the tongue,
And in the heart deſpair!

sp.p: What is here!—a concert of ſorrow? Reſerve your tears, my young miſtreſſes, if your ſmiles will not do the buſineſs better, to work upon the old Baronet in the cauſe of your father—he is going to be called before him—let a parent owe his happineſs to you in the firſt place; and may it be an omen for your lover being as fortunate in the next!

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Raſhly appearing before the juſtice! I have an intereſt and a buſineſs there before you—I fly to execute it—then, Fortune, grant me one more look of her, and take me afterwards to thy direction!

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: The moment is ſtrangely critical to you all. Come on, young ladies, I have a ſtory for you will ſurprize and encourage you.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: We are guided by you—but what can we hope from our ſilly tears, oppoſed to the malice of my father's enemies?

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Every thing—you know not half the intereſt you poſſeſs in the judge.

div.stage: Scene laſt. A large Gothic Hall.
Sir John Contraſt, followed by Trepan.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: I have atteſted the men, in compliance with your beating order—but no more of your occupation—I'm not for purchaſing human fleſh—give me the man (aye, and the woman too) that engages upon frank love and kindneſs, and ſo to other buſineſs.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: One word more, your worſhip. The ſerjeant has juſt apprehended a deſerter. I am ſure your worſhip will be glad to have him convicted—he is the worſt of ſwindlers.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: How do you make him out a ſwindler?

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: He borrows for ſhew the moſt valuable commodities in the nation, courage and fidelity; and ſo raiſes money upon property of which he does not poſſeſs an atom.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Does he ſo?—then bring him in—I'd rather ſee one thief of the public puniſh'd, than an hundred private ones.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: Here, Moll, produce your priſoners.—

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: What, in the name of ſorcery, is this! my ſon in a ſoldier's accoutrements!—I ſhould not have been more ſurprized, if he had been metamorphoſed into a fiſh.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: I was in a fair way to be food for one—I ſhou'd have been ſhark's meet before I got half way to the Weſt Indies.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Stark mad, by all that's fantaſtical!—Can nobody tell me how he was ſeized?

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Seized! why, by that ruffian, neck and heels; and for my accoutrements, you muſt aſk this harpy, who aſſiſted at my toilette.

sp.speaker: CRIMP.
sp.p: A perfect innocent miſtake, as I hope to be pardon'd, your worſhip—I was ſent to ſeek a deſerter—with the beſt legs in England—was it poſſible not to be deceived? but, thanks to Fortune, here's a ſure acquittal—this baggage put him into my hands as the very perſon.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Only a little retaliation, your worſhip—a wolf was in full chace of an innocent lamb, that, to be ſure, I had fooliſhly helped to expoſe to his paws—a trap offered to my hand, and I muſt own I did ſet it, and the wolf was caught, as you ſee. But, indeed, I was coming to your worſhip, to prevent all further harm. I meant honeſtly, and a little merrily I confeſs—I cannot be one without the other for my life.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Plague on you all! this myſtery thickens, inſtead of clearing.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: It is clear, however, my party is out of the ſcrape—and as for the fellow really enliſted—
He is here to fulfill all engagements.

sp.speaker: TREPAN.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my lad of truth; then my twenty guineas are alive again.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee them employ'd; I wou'd have mortgaged ten lives rather than have wanted them.

Mr. Raſhly is charged with informations for killing game to the amount of forty pounds. By aſſiſtance of this gentleman I have made up the ſum. The law is cruel to him; to me it is kind; it enables me to ſhew him the heart he perhaps has doubted.
He is free—and now, Sir, I am your man, and will follow wherever the ſervice of my country leads.

sp.speaker: RENTAL
sp.p: Brave generous fellow! I foreſaw his intent, and wou'd not have baulked it for a kingdom.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Oh, Rental, I am glad you are come; you find me in a wilderneſs here.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: A moment, Sir, and I'm ſure you'll not miſtake your path.

sp.speaker: PEGGY
sp.p: The twiſt is magical, indeed, I think, for I can't undo it—oh, there it is at laſt—
Put up your's again, Mr. Trumore—poor fellow! you'll want it in your new life.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: One of my rouleaus! I have been robbed, I ſee, as well as kidnapped.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Huſſy! how came you by all that money?

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: Perfectly honeſtly—I ſold my miſtreſs and myſelf for it—it is not neceſſary to deliver the goods, for his honour is provided with a miſtreſs; [Pointing to Moll. and my lover is about as well off.—Come, Sir, never look ſo croſs after your money—what fine gentleman wou'd grudge to let an honeſt man out of jail, when he can buy his daughter's modeſty into the bargain?

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Rental, do you ſee into this?

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Clearly, Sir, and it muſt end with reconciling you to your ſon.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p:
How! reconcile me to bribery and debauchery!—never—if the dog cou'd ſucceed with a girl by his face, or his tongue, or his legs, or any thing that nature has given him, why there's a ſort of fair play that might palliate—but there is an unmanlineſs in
vice without paſſion—death! inſipidity is converted into infamy—but where is this Raſhly and his girls?

div.stage: Enter Raſhly—between his daughters—they throw themſelves at Sir John's feet—a long pauſe.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN
sp.p: This Raſhly! this the father of theſe girls! and do not his features deceive me?—who is it I ſee?

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: The ſon I mean to reconcile—who offended upon principles the moſt oppoſite to thoſe you juſt now condemned—the children of his offence—and thanks only to the inheritance of his virtues, that they are not become the puniſhment of his poverty.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: My elder brother come to light!

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Riſe till I am ſure I am awake—this is the confuſion of a delirium.

sp.speaker: RENTAL
sp.p: Why do not you ſpeak, Sir?

sp.speaker: RASHLY.
sp.p:
What form of words will become me? to ſay I repent, would be an injury to the dead and living. I have erred, but I have been happy—one duty I can plead; reſignation to your will—ſo may I thrive in
the deciſion of this anxious moment as I never taxed your juſtice.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN
sp.p: Rental, do you expect I ſhall ever retract?

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: No, Sir, for I was witneſs to the ſolemnity of your vow, that you would protect the father of your little clients againſt all his enemies—right or wrong, they ſhould yield.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Yes, but I little thought how very ſtubborn an old fellow I ſhould have to deal with.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Come forward, clients.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: I am overcome with dread.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Come, I'll make ſhort work of it as uſual—ſo hear all—my decree is made.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Now juſtice and nature!

sp.speaker: SOPHIA.
sp.p: Memory and tenderneſs!

sp.speaker: CONTRAST
sp.p: Caprice and paſſion!

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Deciſion and conſiſtency!—I diſcarded one ſon for a marriage—I have brought up a ſecond—not to marry—but to attempt to debauch his own niece—I'll try what ſort of vexation the other ſex will produce—ſo liſten, girls—take poſſeſſion of this caſtle—it is yours—nay, I only keep my word—you remember how I promiſed to treat the old obſtinate your father was afraid of. This is the houſe of ſelf-correction, and I give you the key.

sp.speaker: SOPHIA and ANNETTE
sp.p: Gratitude—love and joy—

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Up, ye little charmers—your looks have aſked me bleſſing this hour.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: And now for Trumore to compleat the happineſs. Sir John permit me your ear apart.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: So! the confuſion of chances ſeems winding up to a miracle, and quite in my favour—the run of theſe laſt twelve hours exceeds all calculation, ſtrike me pennyleſs—where is that dog La Nippe?

div.stage: Enter La Nippe covered with mud.

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Here he is in a pleaſant plight—

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: Whence, in the devil's name, comeſt thou?

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: From the bottom of a black ditch—how I got there I know no more than the man in the moon—I waked and found myſelf half ſmother'd in dirt, lying like King Log in the fable, with a congreſs of frogs on my back.

sp.speaker: PEGGY.
sp.p: My dear, I hope you are ſatisfied with your bargain, I did my beſt "to ſettle your buſineſs compleatly."

sp.speaker: LA NIPPE.
sp.p: Oh! thou witch of Endor.
sp.stage: [Peg and La Nippe continue to act in dumb ſhew.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Another plot upon me, Rental—but does the young fellow ſay nothing himſelf for his pretenſions.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: I have none, Sir—they aſpired too high when directed to Sophy Raſhly; they muſt ceaſe for ever when I think of Miſs Contraſt.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Now, for the blood of me, I can't ſee that diſtinction. Can you, Contraſt?

sp.speaker: RASHLY.
sp.p: So far from it, Sir, that I think the purity of his attachment to the poor farmer's daughter, is the beſt recommendation to the fortune of the heireſs.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: I confirm the decree—it is exactly my old way—I have not been apt to retract an action, but no man more ready to correct it by doing the reverſe another time. I am now convinced mutual affection makes the only true equality in marriage; and in my preſent humour (I don't know how long 'twill laſt) I wiſh there was not a wedding in the nation formed upon any other intereſt—what ſay you, man of faſhion?

sp.speaker: RASHLY.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't treat my brother's foibles too ſeverely. His zeal, to be eminent, only wants a right turn.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Let him find that turn, and he knows I have where-withal to keep him from the inconvenience of a younger brother, though he loſes Caſtle Manor.

sp.speaker: CONTRAST.
sp.p: I reſign it, and all its appendages. And with all my faults, my brother ſhall find I am neither envious nor mercenary.

[To La Nippe.] Horſes for town inſtantly; there is my true ſphere—and if ever I am caught in a rural intrigue again, may I be tied to an old ram, like my pointers for ſheep-biting, and but • ed into a conſiſtence with the clay of this damned foreſt.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p:
And now to return to my recruit—I promiſed he ſhould be atteſted to-night—and ſo he ſhall—to his
bride—if afterwards his country demands his aſſiſtance—get him a commiſſion, Sophy, and pray for a ſhort end to the war—a prayer in which every good ſubject in the nation will join you.

sp.speaker: TRUMORE.
sp.p: Sir, you have given me a poſſeſſion that makes all other treaſures poor. Witneſs love and truth, how much I deſpiſe the temptation of ambition, when weighed againſt one hour of Sophia's ſociety. But theſe are times when ſervice to the public is a tribute that juſtice and virtue indiſcriminately impoſe upon private happineſs. And the man who refuſes upon their call, a ſacrifice to the exigency of his country, ill deſerves to be a ſharer in her proſperity.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: Sir, the tenants from the wake, in eagerneſs of honeſt joy, preſs to be admitted.

sp.speaker: SIR JOHN.
sp.p: Throw open the doors.

sp.speaker: RENTAL.
sp.p: I hope you will not ſee a countenance that does not expreſs an intereſt in the events of Caſtle Manor.

div.stage: Scene draws to an enlargement of the hall.

l.hi: Partners of my toils and pleaſures,
To this happy ſpot repair;
See how juſtly Fortune meaſures,
Favours to the true and fair:
With choruſſes gay,
Proclaim holiday
In praiſe of the Lord of the Manor;
And happy the ſong,
If it trains old and young
In the leſſons of Caſtle Manor.
When a mutual inclination
Once a glowing ſpark betrays;
Try with tender emulation
Which ſhall firſt excite the blaze:
I plighted my troth
To a generous youth,
I found him at Caſtle Manor.
To one only be kind,
And leave faſhion behind,
'Tis the leſſon of Caſtle Manor.
Gallants, learn from Trumore's ſtory,
To aſſociate in the breaſt
Truth and honour, love and glory,
And to fortune leave the reſt.
My ambition was fame;
From beauty it came,
From beauty at Caſtle Manor.
'Tis an honour to arms
To be led by its charms,
Like the ſoldier of Caſtle Manor.
Briſk and free, but true to duty,
Sure I've play'd an honeſt part;
Would you purchaſe love and beauty,
Be the prize a faithful heart:
Should a knave full of gold
Let him meet me at Caſtle Manor;
A bed in the mire
To cool bis deſire,
Is the leſſon of Caſtle Manor.
Tho' I trip in my expreſſion,
Critics, lend a patient ear—
If coquetting be tranſgreſſion—
Siſterhood, be not ſevere.
To love while we live
And all faults to forgive,
Is the leſſon of Caſtle Manor:
Be friends to our cauſe
And make your applauſe,
A new bleſſing at Caſtle Manor.
